I would like to be able to use the apple pen again in Minecraft. I‚Äôve been playing Minecraft for over 10 years. When I was able to use the apple pen it made Minecraft way more fun. Then after one of the updates a few years ago it was disabled. I then just stop playing the game. I go back in every 6 months to see if it was fixed but still nothing. üò≠

@TrendyMom4762 for now, all we can do is petition in this post. But my bet is that the Apple Pencil is a **specific feature** exclusive to some models of iPad. Since Bedrock edition is on so many different platforms, coding in a feature that affects a small playerbase might not be a priority. While it would be awesome to see the game react to the Pencil differently than a finger, the best we can hope for is the ability to replicate touches with the stylus.
Please allow the use of Apple Pencil!

It would also be nice to take into account the features of Apple Pencil Pro such as Haptic feedback for selection of items and "Barrel roll" to sort how many times to select by rolling the pencil to the left or right. Also you can include the squeeze function to open up the crafting menu or inventory. For the Double Tap on the Apple Pencil Pro you could use to sort through items in your hotbar. And for all Apple Pencil models other than the USB-C one, use the pressure sensitivity to determine if you are just "hovering" over a block and when you press down on the pencil, to place the block you are holding or activate the function of the item you have in your hand. That aforementioned pressure sensitivity would allow you to keep the pencil in contact with the iPad screen. At last you can use tilt sensitivity to determine how fast the camera in all 3 view modes turns. The farther you tilt the pencil the faster the spin and this will allow you to make slow and fine adjustments to your view angle.
I want urdu in minecraft
same, it should be

Even if they need help translating it, there are over 100 million well educated native Urdu speakers that could help them, and Arabic text is already supported by Minecraft, so the text is not a problem. They should add it ASAP. Matter of fact, I could help them translate.

I agree.
Minecraft isn't a kid's game, there are adults who play and enjoy this game. I don't see the problem if I want to build a Bar and name potions after drinks. It's so invigorating not being able to give a potion a clever name because Minecraft thinks the word tequila is profane. I understand people can be immature and post gross stuff in servers or whatever, but there should be some fairground for players of all ages. The profanity filter as an option should have already been implemented.
It is quite possible to turn off the "F3" menu completely, the coordinates too. For a long time already there is magnetite, compasses, maps, landmarks.

This would be beneficial for both bedrock and java edition. Most of the info list on the java debug menu is not needed for survival. However, in bedrock edition there is no good indication of useful functions. The more advance features should be there only with cheats enable, while the more useful features such as coordinates, light levels, and biome indicators should be included without cheats.

To those who voted for this, it's a duplicate of https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/360028847492-Split-Screen-for-Windows-10 please add your votes to it as well.

I'm in love with the idea of adding descriptions to items in minecraft as a subtle way to inform new players while still letting them figure out things by themselves, and I have a few suggestions to expand on the idea:
‚Ä¢ When hovering above an item as a new player it could be overwhelming to read all the information presented, especially when doing so on enchanted armor, trimmed armor, banners ext. So I suggest that for the Java Edition a key would be assigned to reveal the item description and for Bedrock Edition the description could be revealed in a different tab in the inventory.
‚Ä¢ The descriptions have to be limited to the point of view of the player character meaning no information that isn't known to them such as building a nether portal should be presented. Instead the descriptions should present the items as they appear with additional hints to their potential uses, E.G. Obsidian: "A tough rock that is formed by rapidly cooling lava. It seems to have some magical properties that could be useful." This lets the player look for recipes using the obsidian & discover ruined portals and make their own conclusions.
‚Ä¢ This have the potential to give some lore insights through the items to enchantments, The Nether, mobs ext. E.G Sculk catalyst: "It seems to use the magical energy of fallen mobs to sustain itself. Makes you wonder what happend in the Deep Dark?"

It's not meant to be a way to give the player a fixed path, it's a way to give guidance and encourage creativity
